data: Dedication of an altar for Hestia
Quadrangular block of stone, damaged around the edges but essentially intact; parts of the face still covered with stucco.
six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.
3rd or 2nd century BCE, lettering of the early-mid Hellenistic.
Found in the vicinity of the church of S. Pancrazio in 1861.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 22-03-2017
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2009
The collection in the "Casina degli Inglesi" consists of 20 inscriptions, 1 statue, two busts, a few mosaics, a 2nd C AD marble sarcophagus and some modern art

dedication of an altar for hestia
ISic001258. Dedication of an altar for Hestia

1ἀμφὶ παραστάσι ταῖσδε Σαράπιδος Ἑστίαι ἁγνὸν
2βωμὸν Βαρκαῖος Καρνεάδης ἔθετο
3Εὐκρίτου υἱός ξεῖνε ὁ νεωκόρος ἅ θ’ ὁμόλεκτρο[ς]
4Πυθιὰς ἁ κείνου καὶ θυγάτηρ Ἐρασώ
5ἀνθ’ ὧν ὦ κραίνουσα Διὸς μεγαλαυχέας οἴκους
6θυμαρὴν βιοτᾶς ὄλβον ἔχοιεν ἀεί.

1ΑΜΦΙΠΑΡΑΣΤΑΣΙΤΑΙΣΔΕΣΑΡΑΠΙΔΟΣΕΣΤΙΑΙΑΓΝΟΝ
2ΒΩΜΟΝΒΑΡΚΑΙΟΣΚΑΡΝΕΑΔΗΣΕΘΕΤΟ
3ΕΥΚΡΙΤΟΥΥΙΟΣΞΕΙΝΕΟΝΕΩΚΟΡΟΣΑΘΟΜΟΛΕΚΤΡΟ[.]
4ΠΥΘΙΑΣΑΚΕΙΝΟΥΚΑΙΘΥΓΑΤΗΡΕΡΑΣΩ
5ΑΝΘΩΝΩΚΡΑΙΝΟΥΣΑΔΙΟΣΜΕΓΑΛΑΥΧΕΑΣΟΙΚΟΥΣ
6ΘΥΜΑΡΗΝΒΙΟΤΑΣΟΛΒΟΝΕΧΟΙΕΝΑΕΙ

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text of IG checked against photograph;
  • 3: Final sigma no longer visible on stone (edge is chipped)

English translation

Giorgia Capra

Near these doorposts to the temple of Sarapis, Karneades of Barke, the temple-warden, son of Eukritos, dedicated this sacred altar to Hestia, visitor, together with his wife Pythia and his daughter Erasos. In exchange, you reigning over Zeus' magnificent house, that they may always have well-pleasing happiness of life.

Near these doorposts to the temple of Sarapis, Karneades of Barke, the temple-warden, son of Eukritos, dedicated this sacred altar to Hestia, visitor, together with his wife Pythia and his daughter Erasos. In exchange, you reigning over Zeus' magnificent house, that they may always have well-pleasing happiness of life.

Quadrangular block of stone, damaged around the edges but essentially intact; parts of the face still covered with stucco.

limestone altar 67 4.5 33.5

six lines of Greek letters in a recessed field 23 cm high, with consistent left margin, uneven right margin, at times rather compressed on the right (e.g. line 5), and vacat below.

chiselled

Neat and regular letters without serfis (but slight terminal marks to the strokes). Alpha with straight cross bar, beta with equal closed eyes, epsilon with short middle stroke, theta slightly ovoid with detached middle bar, kappa with short arms, mu with almost vertical first and last, and three-quarter mid-strokes; xsi with three horizontal bars, lowest the longest; omicron smaller and mid-line, pi with equal vertical strokes; rho rounded closed eye; sigma with very slightly open top and bottom strokes; phi with round eye, slightly extended vertical; omega mostly circular, slightly open, short horizontal feet.

ἀμφὶ παραστάσι ταῖσδε Σαράπιδος Ἑστίαι ἁγνὸν βωμὸν Βαρκαῖος Καρνεάδης ἔθετο Εὐκρίτου υἱός ξεῖνε ὁ νεωκόρος ἅ θ’ ὁμόλεκτρος Πυθιὰς ἁ κείνου καὶ θυγάτηρ Ἐρασώ ἀνθ’ ὧν ὦ κραίνουσα Διὸς μεγαλαυχέας οἴκους θυμαρὴν βιοτᾶς ὄλβον ἔχοιεν ἀεί.
Text of IG checked against photograph Final sigma no longer visible on stone (edge is chipped)

Near these doorposts to the temple of Sarapis, Karneades of Barke, the temple-warden, son of Eukritos, dedicated this sacred altar to Hestia, visitor, together with his wife Pythia and his daughter Erasos. In exchange, you reigning over Zeus' magnificent house, that they may always have well-pleasing happiness of life.
